title: Engine Management System Sensors

body.body: Eng Mngt Sensors Description TD1; TH1

- situated on the left side of the throttle body. The MAP sensor provides information to the engine ECM which is used at very small throttle openings to provide accurate engine load indications to the engine ECM. This degree of engine load accuracy allows the engine ECM to make very small adjustments to fuel and ignition which would otherwise not be possible from throttle angle data alone.
Temperature and Manifold Absolute Pressure (TMAP) sensor
- situated in the right side of the airbox. It is a combined temperature and pressure sensor.

The pressure component of the sensor measures atmospheric air pressure in the airbox. With this information, the amount of fuel injected is adjusted to suit the prevailing conditions. As the density of the air (and therefore the amount of oxygen available to ignite the fuel) changes with temperature, this temperature is also measured by the sensor. Changes in air temperature entering the airbox (and therefore air density) are compensated for by adjusting the amount of fuel injected to a level consistent with clean combustion and low emissions.
- situated on the clutch lever. The clutch must be pulled in for the starter motor to operate.

- situated in the crankcase, above the alternator rotor. The crankshaft position sensor detects movement of teeth on the alternator rotor. The teeth give a reference point from which the actual crankshaft position is calculated. The crankshaft position sensor information is used by the engine ECM to determine engine speed and crankshaft position in relation to the point where fuel is injected and ignition of the fuel occurs.

- situated at the rear left side of the cylinder head near the oil pressure switch. Coolant temperature information, received by the engine ECM, is used to optimise fuelling at all engine temperatures and to calculate hot and cold start fuelling requirements.

- There are two oxygen sensors. The first is situated in the exhaust header pipe close to the cylinder head. primary oxygen sensor constantly feeds information to the engine ECM on the content of the exhaust gases. Based on this information, adjustments to air/fuel ratio are made. On some models, a secondary oxygen sensor is situated in the exhaust after the catalyst and is used to assess the condition of the catalytic converter by comparing signal data against the primary oxygen sensor.
- situated at the top of the side stand leg. If the side stand is in the down position, the engine will not run unless the transmission is in neutral.

- situated between the frame tubes rearward of the headstock. The fall detection switch will detect if the motorcycle is on its side and will cut power to the engine ECM immediately. This prevents the engine from running and the fuel pump from delivering fuel. In the event of a fall, the switch is reset by returning the bike to an upright position and switching the ignition off then back on again.

- situated in the lower crankcase, below the drive chain front sprocket. The gear position sensor provides the engine ECM with selected gear information. This is used to prevent the engine from starting if the transmission is in gear. The sensor also provides information to the neutral lamp in the instruments.

search: Engine Management System Sensors
System Sensors
Manifold Absolute Pressure (MAP) sensor

- situated on the left side of the throttle body. The MAP sensor provides information to the engine ECM which is used at very small throttle openings to provide accurate engine load indications to the engine ECM. This degree of engine load accuracy allows the engine ECM to make very small adjustments to fuel and ignition which would otherwise not be possible from throttle angle data alone.
Temperature and Manifold Absolute Pressure (TMAP) sensor
- situated in the right side of the airbox. It is a combined temperature and pressure sensor.

The pressure component of the sensor measures atmospheric air pressure in the airbox. With this information, the amount of fuel injected is adjusted to suit the prevailing conditions. As the density of the air (and therefore the amount of oxygen available to ignite the fuel) changes with temperature, this temperature is also measured by the sensor. Changes in air temperature entering the airbox (and therefore air density) are compensated for by adjusting the amount of fuel injected to a level consistent with clean combustion and low emissions.
Clutch switch
- situated on the clutch lever. The clutch must be pulled in for the starter motor to operate.
Crankshaft position sensor

- situated in the crankcase, above the alternator rotor. The crankshaft position sensor detects movement of teeth on the alternator rotor. The teeth give a reference point from which the actual crankshaft position is calculated. The crankshaft position sensor information is used by the engine ECM to determine engine speed and crankshaft position in relation to the point where fuel is injected and ignition of the fuel occurs.
Engine coolant temperature sensor

- situated at the rear left side of the cylinder head near the oil pressure switch. Coolant temperature information, received by the engine ECM, is used to optimise fuelling at all engine temperatures and to calculate hot and cold start fuelling requirements.
Oxygen sensors

- There are two oxygen sensors. The first is situated in the exhaust header pipe close to the cylinder head. primary oxygen sensor constantly feeds information to the engine ECM on the content of the exhaust gases. Based on this information, adjustments to air/fuel ratio are made. On some models, a secondary oxygen sensor is situated in the exhaust after the catalyst and is used to assess the condition of the catalytic converter by comparing signal data against the primary oxygen sensor.
Side stand switch
- situated at the top of the side stand leg. If the side stand is in the down position, the engine will not run unless the transmission is in neutral.
Fall Detection Switch

- situated between the frame tubes rearward of the headstock. The fall detection switch will detect if the motorcycle is on its side and will cut power to the engine ECM immediately. This prevents the engine from running and the fuel pump from delivering fuel. In the event of a fall, the switch is reset by returning the bike to an upright position and switching the ignition off then back on again.
Gear position sensor

- situated in the lower crankcase, below the drive chain front sprocket. The gear position sensor provides the engine ECM with selected gear information. This is used to prevent the engine from starting if the transmission is in gear. The sensor also provides information to the neutral lamp in the instruments.
